full_text:
Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 773 Filed 08/10/22 Page 26 of 29 LCRVMAXT
1 deliberate later than that, you're most welcome to do so.
2 Please let me know by note when you wish to stop, but the default going forward will be 6 p.m., unless anyone indicates to Ms. Williams that that constitutes a hardship. Okay?
3 MS. MENNINGER: That would be our concern, your Honor, obviously, that some of them do have hardships.
4 THE COURT: As I did last time, I'm going to tell them the default will be 6; but if it's a hardship, they should let Ms. Williams know, in which case -- so, again, the language will be, If deliberations are not complete starting tomorrow, I'd like you to make yourselves available to deliberate until at least 6 p.m. Of course, if you all agree to deliberate later than that, you're most welcome to do so. Please just let me know by note when you wish to stop. But the default going forward will be 6 p.m., unless anyone indicates to Ms. Williams on their way out that that is a hardship. Okay?
5 MS. MOE: Yes, your Honor. Thank you.
6 MS. MENNINGER: Your Honor, we would object to adding the "If deliberations are not complete." I think that any kind of suggestion that the deliberations should be resolving by a certain time or not resolving could potentially --
7 THE COURT: That is the precise language I used last week in asking if they wanted to sit on Thursday. It didn't cause them to think that they had to complete their deliberations.
8 SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300 DOJ-OGR-00017330
